title: 110_hr288
content: The "Notch Baby Act of 2007" establishes a new guaranteed minimum primary insurance amount for those eligible during a transitional period. Section 215(a) of the Social Security Act is amended to include provisions for individuals becoming eligible for old-age insurance benefits between 1978 and 1989. This amendment ensures that the primary insurance amount is adjusted to include a transitional increase amount if applicable. For individuals eligible for old-age insurance benefits between 1978 and 1989, the primary insurance amount is adjusted to include a transitional increase amount if applicable. For individuals eligible for old-age insurance benefits between 1978 and 1989, the primary insurance amount is adjusted to include a transitional increase amount, calculated based on the excess under former law and the applicable percentage in relation to the year of eligibility. Individuals eligible for old-age insurance benefits between 1979 and 1988 will receive a transitional increase amount based on the applicable percentage for the respective year of eligibility: 60% for 1979-1980, 35% for 1981-1982, 30% for 1983-1984, 25% for 1985-1986, and 10% for 1987-1988. Between 1979 and 1988, individuals eligible for old-age insurance benefits will receive a transitional increase amount based on the applicable percentage for the respective year of eligibility. The term 'excess under former law' refers to the difference between the applicable former law primary insurance amount and the amount that would be the individual's primary insurance amount if computed under this section. The term 'excess under former law' for individuals refers to the difference between the applicable former law primary insurance amount and the amount that would be the individual's primary insurance amount if computed under this section. The term 'applicable former law primary insurance amount' is defined as the individual's primary insurance amount calculated under specific conditions outlined in subparagraph (C)(i), and modified as per subparagraph (E). The individual's primary insurance amount is computed or recomputed under specific conditions outlined in subparagraph (C)(i) and modified as per subparagraph (E), with certain provisions and exceptions applied. The individual's primary insurance amount is determined under specific conditions outlined in subparagraph (E), with exceptions and provisions applied. The individual's primary insurance amount is determined based on specific conditions outlined in subparagraph (E), with exceptions and provisions applied. The base years for calculation may include calendar years after 1950 (or 1936 if applicable) until the individual reaches age 61, plus the 3 calendar years with the highest total wages and self-employment income. Additionally, certain adjustments are made to the calculations as specified in the paragraph. The primary insurance amount for an individual is determined based on specific conditions outlined in subparagraph (E), with exceptions and provisions applied. Certain adjustments are made to the calculations to ensure a greater amount for the individual. SEC. 3. EFFECTIVE DATE AND RELATED RULES. The amendments made by this Act are effective as if they were part of the Social Security Amendments of 1977, with no benefit increases before January 2007. Individual entitled to benefits in December 2006 may have their benefits recomputed to reflect increases. The primary insurance amount under Title II of the Social Security Act can be increased for months before January 2007. Individuals entitled to benefits in December 2006 may have their benefits recomputed to reflect increases based on specific sections of the Act. The Commissioner of Social Security will recompute the primary insurance amount for individuals entitled to benefits before January 2007 to reflect amendments made by the Social Security Amendments of 1977.
